dialogue_line_replacements.text: Trabajo en un colegio. Enseño matemáticas.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: I work at a school. I teach maths.

dialogue_line_replacements.text: No, no como en el colegio. Vuelvo a casa para comer.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: No, I don't eat at school. I go back home to eat.

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: In Spain, 'vosotros' is the second-person plural: 'vosotros trabajáis, coméis, vivís'. This is completely absent in Latin America, which uses 'ustedes' for all plural. Learning vosotros conjugations is essential for speaking with Spaniards.
cultural_notes_overrides.gestures: Counting verb forms on fingers is a universal teacher technique in Spain — holding up fingers for each person: yo, tú, él/ella, nosotros, vosotros, ellos.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: 'Conducir' (to drive) is used in Spain, while Latin America uses 'manejar'. 'Coger' (to take/catch) is common in Spain for taking transport: 'Cojo el metro' — but this word has a vulgar meaning in Latin America, so avoid it there.
cultural_notes_overrides.distincion: Vosotros present tense: -AR → trabajáis, -ER → coméis, -IR → vivís. The accent on the ending is important: habláis [aˈblais], coméis [koˈmeis], vivís [biˈbis].
